reviewText: Each disc is well produced and well researched. If you are interested in understanding whether archeology synchs up with the stories in the Bible, you'll find this worth your while. What I liked about it is the "we report you decide" approach. BnB Beatles Depot
summary: Well done and keeps your interest

reviewText: This is a wonderful addition to anyones video library.  They approach the subjects in a non-religious, scientific manner.  I like that.  It's "OK, here's what the Bible says, here's what we know, here's what we can prove. Now go make up your mind."  They don't set out to debunk the 'religiousity' of any of it, just to present the facts based on what we know.  Plus, the visuals of the area are unbelievable.  This is perfect for anyone with an interest in Christianity.

reviewText: I watched this series every week on the Discovery Channel and enjoyed it very much, although I disagree with some of its findings.  If a thought-provoking (though at times controversial) set of documentaries on the Bible is your cup of tea, then this box is for you.I would give this set 5 stars, if it weren't for the fact that there was space on these discs for two more programs in the series.  Discs 1 and 3 contain only three episodes, while disc 2 has four.  The program "Who Was Moses?" would have fit rather nicely on the first DVD about the Old Testament.  And if the episode on the second disc called "The Real Disciples" had been placed on the third disc, titled "Mysteries of the Apostles", there would have been room on disc 2 for perhaps the best documentary of the entire series, "Mary, the Mother of Jesus".  I think the Discovery Channel and the BBC dropped the ball a bit on this set but, overall, it is still worth the purchase.
Title: N/A

reviewText: A great series by the BBC, well presented by Avery Brooks. These documentaries take us back (Old & New Testament stories), present what probably happened or how/why an event occurred & probable scientific explanation of the specific occurance. Issues like these are difficult to navigate & are often controversial, other times there are conflicting views & the documentary has to be committed to one of the views. Example is the view that Simon Peter died in Rome (Roman Catholic view) and the other that he died in Jerusalem (Tabor / Jacobovici). The former is presented here. The series are also insightful & educational with beautiful re-nactments of particular stories. The stories really come alive & real people eventually start to emerge! A highly recommended viewing!
